parts: my power keeps tripping even though all heavy duty appliances (like air conditioning) have been turned off, and the only source of electrical usage are some ordinary fans and lights which have never caused any problem. How can I diagnose the cause?>

thoughts.content: The user's power keeps tripping, even though heavy-duty appliances are off. I think this might involve a Residual Current Circuit Breaker (RCCB) trip due to earth leakage, or an MCB trip caused by overcurrent. In Singapore, homes use RCD and MCBs, so I need to provide step-by-step diagnostics. I’d suggest checking if the main breaker trips and isolating circuits, turning them on one by one. Also, testing the RCCB with its button and using a multimeter to check for leakage could help pinpoint the fault.

parts:
Below is a systematic, safety-first workflow you can follow before calling a licensed electrician. It is written for a typical Singapore HDB / landed-home consumer unit (a main Residual-Current Circuit Breaker - RCCB / ELCB plus several Miniature Circuit Breakers - MCBs). If your switchboard uses a different layout, adapt accordingly.

---

## 1  Confirm **what** is tripping

| Symptom | Likely Device | Meaning |
|---------|---------------|---------|
| **Whole house** loses power (all MCBs drop or stay up but there is no power) | **Main incoming breaker** (sometimes labelled “MAIN” or “DB Incomer”) | Severe fault or SP Group supply issues |
| **Main RCCB / ELCB** drops but individual MCBs stay up | **Earth-leakage fault** ≥ 30 mA somewhere on ANY circuit |
| A **single MCB** drops | **Over-current or short-circuit** on that circuit only |

Take a photo of the consumer unit as-is immediately after the next trip so you know exactly which lever released.

---

## 2  Rule out an overloaded or shorted **branch circuit** (MCB trips)

1. **Isolate that branch**  
   - Leave the suspect MCB **OFF**.  
   - Reset everything else. If supply now holds, the problem is inside that branch only.

2. **Unplug all appliances** on that circuit (fans, chargers, lamps, router, etc.).  
   Older phone chargers and plug-in LED lamps are notorious for internal shorts.

3. **Inspect visible cabling & sockets** for scorch marks, heat, or a “fishy” smell (melting insulation).

4. **Plug items back one-by-one**, waiting 30 – 60 s each time.  
   - The guilty appliance will trip the MCB almost instantly.  
   - Replace or repair it; do **not** keep resetting.

> **Tip**: Label plugs or use a plug-in breaker finder so you know which outlet is on which MCB for future faults.

---

## 3  Chase an **earth-leakage** fault (RCCB / ELCB trips)

When the RCCB opens it means live–earth or neutral–earth leakage ≥ 30 mA on **any** circuit.

### 3.1  Divide-and-conquer test

1. **Turn off every MCB.**  
   Reset the RCCB (it should now stay ON).

2. **Turn MCBs on one at a time**, leaving 10–20 s between.  
   - When the RCCB drops, the *last* MCB you turned on (or its load) introduced the leakage.

3. **Narrow further**: unplug devices on that MCB one-by-one as in § 2.  
   - Fans accumulate dust + humidity; the motor windings or speed controller can begin leaking after years of use.

### 3.2  Hidden culprits to check

| Possible cause | Why it leaks |
|----------------|-------------|
| **Water ingress** in ceiling lights / bathroom heaters | Condensation creates an earth path |
| **Rodent-chewed cable** in parapet or false ceiling | Exposed copper contacts earth screen |
| **Failing LED driver** or screw-in LED bulb | Switching power supply capacitors leak |
| **Loose neutral or earth termination** inside socket | Arcing → carbon tracks → leakage |

If you cannot find the appliance, the wiring itself may be compromised—time for a megohmmeter (insulation-resistance) test by a professional.

---

## 4  Environmental factors to verify

| Check | Why it matters |
|-------|----------------|
| **Recent heavy rain / roof leak?** | Moisture in junction boxes causes earth leakage |
| **Renovation drilling nearby?** | A nicked cable insulation worsens over days |
| **Extension cords daisy-chained?** | Adds resistance → heat → conductor insulation failure |

---

## 5  Instrumented diagnostics (if you have the gear)

1. **Clamp-meter with mA range on earth conductor** of suspect circuit → shows live leakage directly.  
2. **Thermal camera** (even a smartphone add-on) scans sockets & MCCB tails for hot spots.  
3. **Insulation-resistance tester** (“megger”) at 500 VDC checks each circuit end-to-end; anything < 1 MΩ is suspect.

Unless you are experienced, treat these as *information gathering*—the corrective work still needs a licensed electrician.

---

## 6  When to stop and call an electrician immediately

- RCCB trips **immediately** even with every MCB OFF → possible faulty RCCB or upstream fault.
- Burnt smell, scorch marks, or melted plastic.
- Repeated trips within seconds of reset despite no load connected.
- You are uncomfortable or unsure about any measurement—electric shock risk is non-trivial.

---

## 7  Preventive moves after repair

1. **Tighten all terminal screws** (torque driver) during annual inspection—loose neutrals mimic leakage.  
2. **Replace aging fans & LED drivers** proactively after ~8 years.  
3. **Keep fittings dry**—install IP-rated fixtures in bathrooms/outdoors.  
4. **Label circuits clearly** inside the consumer unit lid for faster future isolation.  
5. **Test the RCCB monthly** using its “TEST” button (SP Group and EMA recommend this).

---

### Bottom line

A systematic isolate-and-re-energise sequence will locate *most* tripping causes. Earth-leakage faults, especially intermittent ones, can hide in seemingly innocent devices like fans or in ageing cable insulation; resist the temptation to keep “just resetting” because leakage currents that trip an RCCB are already in the shock-hazard range. If you cannot narrow it down to a single plug-in appliance quickly (within an hour), engage a licensed electrician—they have insulation testers and can open the distribution board safely.

Stay safe, and don’t hesitate to bring in professional help once the basics above are exhausted.
it was caused by a 6 year old phone charger!

That makes complete sense—cheap-switch-mode phone chargers are one of the most common sources of earth-leakage and short-circuit faults once they’ve aged a few years.

---

### Why that old charger tripped the breaker

| Failure mode | What happens inside | How it shows up on your board |
|--------------|--------------------|--------------------------------|
| **Input filter capacitors dry out** | ESR rises → heat → dielectric breakdown → live conductor touches shielding | RCCB trips (live-to-earth leakage) |
| **Transformer insulation cracks** | Primary and secondary windings arc | RCCB or sometimes the branch MCB trips |
| **Solder joints go “cold”** | High resistance → local hot-spot → carbon track to ground | Intermittent trips, sometimes a burnt smell |
| **Plastic case fatigue** | Hairline fracture lets in moisture or lets pins flex against PCB | Random leakage, especially in humid weather |

Because the charger is double-insulated and sealed, you don’t see the damage—your RCCB did its job by cutting power as soon as leakage exceeded ≈30 mA.

---

### What to do next

1. **Dispose safely**  
   - Treat it as e-waste (most malls in Singapore have ALBA e-waste bins).  
   - Do **not** put it back into service “just for low-power uses”.

2. **Check the socket**  
   - Make sure the charger didn’t scorch the outlet contacts; replace the wall plate if there’s any discoloration.

3. **Inspect similar devices**  
   Any other low-cost USB bricks or LED bulb drivers of the same vintage should be considered suspect. If the plastics feel unusually warm or the label text has browned, retire them.

4. **Buy replacements with these cues**  
   - Safety marks: Singapore “SPS”/“SAFETY”, UK “BS1363”, or EU “CE” + “EN62368-1” tested.  
   - Power budget headroom: use a 30 W model for a phone that normally draws 15 W so components run cool.  
   - Integrated over-current/over-temperature protection (look for reputable brands or teardown reviews).

5. **Add a periodic check**  
   Every six months, walk the house and feel each plug-top for warmth after 10 minutes of use; anything overly warm (> 50 °C case temperature) deserves replacement.

---

### Good practice going forward

- **Label your RCCB & MCBs** if you haven’t yet; knowing which circuit feeds your charging stations speeds up future fault-finding.
- **Test the RCCB monthly** (press the T-button). If it doesn’t trip instantly, get it replaced—better to find out now than when you really need it.
- **Use a multi-port charger on one spot-checked outlet** rather than many individual bricks; fewer failure points and easier to monitor.

If you’d like recommendations on reliable, safety-certified chargers—or anything else power-related—just let me know. Glad you nailed the culprit before anything worse happened!
